semantic_title: Acute Respiratory Failure as Secondary Diagnosis Coding Rules
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 10. Chapter 10: Diseases of the Respiratory System > b. Acute Respiratory Failure > 2. Acute respiratory failure as secondary diagnosis

content.full_text: Respiratory failure may be listed as a secondary diagnosis if it occurs after admission, or if it is present on admission, but does not meet the definition of principal diagnosis. (Evidence: pg no: 56, L63-L64)
content.summary: Conditions for coding acute respiratory failure as secondary diagnosis based on timing and principal diagnosis criteria (Evidence: pg no: 56, L63-L64)
key_concepts: Post-admission respiratory failure (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
Present on admission but not principal (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
Principal diagnosis definition criteria (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Respiratory failure may be secondary diagnosis if it occurs after admission (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
detailed_rules.explanation: When respiratory failure develops during hospitalization, it should be coded as secondary diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Respiratory failure may be secondary if present on admission but does not meet principal diagnosis definition (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
detailed_rules.explanation: When respiratory failure is present at admission but another condition is chiefly responsible for admission (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
common_applications: Respiratory failure secondary to other acute condition
Multiple conditions with different primary focus
Chronic respiratory failure with acute exacerbation of other condition

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify presence of respiratory failure
Step 2: Determine timing - present on admission or developed after
Step 3: If present on admission, assess if it meets principal diagnosis criteria
Step 4: If post-admission or not principal, code as secondary diagnosis

code_ranges.description: Acute respiratory failure (Evidence: pg no: 56, L63)
code_ranges.requirement: Code as secondary when criteria met
usage_rules: Use as secondary if occurs after admission (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
Use as secondary if present on admission but not principal (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)

code_ranges.description: Acute and chronic respiratory failure (Evidence: pg no: 56, L63)
code_ranges.requirement: Code as secondary when criteria met
usage_rules: Use as secondary if occurs after admission (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
Use as secondary if present on admission but not principal (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)

references_to.title: Acute respiratory failure as principal diagnosis
references_to.explanation: Defines when respiratory failure is not principal diagnosis

referenced_by.title: Sequencing of acute respiratory failure and another acute condition
referenced_by.explanation: Provides context for complex sequencing decisions

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient develops respiratory failure after surgery
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient admitted for elective surgery, developed acute respiratory failure on postoperative day 2
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify primary reason for admission (surgery)
Step 2: Note respiratory failure developed after admission
Step 3: Code surgical condition as principal
Step 4: Code respiratory failure as secondary

correct_coding.sequencing: Surgical condition principal, respiratory failure secondary
correct_coding.rationale: Respiratory failure occurred after admission, making it secondary diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Post-admission respiratory failure should not be principal
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Making post-admission complication the principal diagnosis

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with respiratory failure and MI, MI is primary focus
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient admitted with acute MI, also has acute respiratory failure present on admission
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify both conditions present on admission
Step 2: Determine which is chiefly responsible for admission
Step 3: If MI is primary focus, code as principal
Step 4: Code respiratory failure as secondary

correct_coding.rationale: Respiratory failure present on admission but MI is chiefly responsible for admission (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)

incorrect_coding.rationale: MI should be principal if it's the chief reason for admission
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not properly identifying which condition is chiefly responsible

breakdown.Secondary: Acute respiratory failure as secondary (Evidence: pg no: 56, L63-L64)

examples.rationale: Respiratory failure present but not the chief reason for admission (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)

best_practices: Carefully assess timing of respiratory failure development (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
Evaluate which condition is chiefly responsible for admission (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
common_mistakes: Making post-admission respiratory failure the principal diagnosis
Not properly assessing principal diagnosis criteria
tips: Post-admission development automatically makes condition secondary (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
Present on admission doesn't automatically mean principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 56, L64)
implementation_notes: Requires careful documentation review for timing
Must apply principal diagnosis definition consistently
clinical_context: Respiratory failure can develop as complication during hospitalization
Multiple acute conditions may be present with different levels of severity
Timing of condition development affects coding sequence
